When a small group of organisms (a small population) is separated from the main population from which it came (e.g., when they migrate over a mountain range or across a river, or when they colonize a new island, so that they cannot easily return), they often find themselves in a different environment than before.

This new environment has different resources and different competitors, so that the new population needs different characteristics or adaptations to be a strong competitor, as opposed to what it needed before.
The original population has not changed at all. It still needs the same adaptations as before.
Over time, the new population adapts to its new environment, and then it looks less and less like the other population.
After thousands or even millions of years two populations look so different that they can no longer be assigned to the same species.
We call this process speciation, which simply means the creation of new species. Speciation is an unavoidable consequence and a very important part of evolution.

Technological determinism is a term that encompasses a wide range of ideas in practice, from the technological push or the technological imperative to the strict sense that human destiny is determined by a logic underlying science and its manifestation in technology.

Most interpretations of technological determinism share two general views. On the one hand, that the development of technology follows a path that is largely outside of cultural or political influence, and on the other hand, that technology itself has "effects" on societies that are more inherent than socially determined.
One could say that the automobile is unavoidably linked to the development of roads.
However, a nationwide road network for only a small number of cars is not economically viable. Therefore, new production methods are being developed to reduce the cost of car ownership.

The widespread ownership of automobiles also leads to a higher number of accidents on the roads, which in turn leads to the invention of new technologies in the medical field to repair damaged bodies.

After his farewell by Congress on July 4, a handwritten, signed by the President John Hancock and the Secretary Charles Thomson, was sent a few blocks away to the printing house of John Dunlap.
During the night, between 150 and 200 copies were made, which are now known as "Dunlap broadsides".
The first public reading of the document took place by John Nixon in the Independence Hall courtyard on July 8.
One was sent to George Washington on July 6, which he read to his troops in New York on July 9. A copy reached London on August 10.
Of the 25 Dunlap broadsides that still exist, they are the oldest known copies of the document. The original handwritten document has not survived the ages.

Fortunately, drivers tend to behave consistently; therefore, traffic flows have a certain consistency and can be roughly represented mathematically.

Content theories focus on finding what moves or appeals to people.

In general, two behavioural patterns can emerge when managers begin to lead their former colleagues. At one end of the spectrum is the attempt to remain "one of the boys" (or one of the girls).
This type of manager has problems making unpopular decisions, enforcing disciplinary measures, evaluating performance, assigning responsibilities, and holding employees accountable.
At the other end of the spectrum, one becomes an unrecognizable individual who does everything differently from the team and takes everything for themselves.
In the end, the team leader is responsible for the success and failure of the team.
This behavior often leads to conflicts between the leaders and the rest of the team.
Virtual teams are managed according to the same standards of excellence as conventional teams, but there are subtle differences.
Virtual team members often have the function of a contact point for their immediate physical group.
They often have more autonomy than traditional team members, since their teams meet in different time zones that may not be considered by local management.
The presence of a real "invisible team" (Larson and LaFasto 1989, p. 109) is also a unique feature of a virtual team.
"The "invisible team" is the leadership team that each member reports to. The invisible team sets the standards for each member."

Research in the field of AI includes the creation of machines to automate tasks that require intelligent behavior.
Examples of this are control, setting up strategies and time plans, the ability to answer customer questions and diagnoses, as well as handwriting, voice and face recognition.

Field trips are an important part of every school class. Often a teacher would like to take her students to places where a bus trip is not an option.
Virtual field trips are a technological solution. Students can view museum exhibits, visit an aquarium or admire beautiful works of art from the classroom.
Sharing a virtual excursion is also a great way to reflect on a trip and share experiences with future classes.

For example, students at the Bennet School in North Carolina design a website every year about their trip to the state capital. The website is redesigned every year, but the previous versions remain online and serve as a scrapbook.

Blogs can also help to improve the writing skills of students. Although students at the beginning of their blogging experience often have a sloppy grammar and spelling, this usually changes when there is an audience.
Since students are often a very critical audience, the blog author makes an effort to improve his writing style in order to avoid criticism.
Blogging "forces students to learn more about the world around them." The need to attract an audience inspires students to write cleverly and interestingly (Toto, 2004).
Blogging is a tool that inspires collaboration and encourages students to continue learning outside the traditional school day.

The appropriate use of blogs can enable students to become more analytical and critical; by reacting to Internet materials, students can define their positions in the context of other texts and express their own perspectives on certain topics (Oravec, 2002).

The present-day Casablanca was founded by Berber fishermen in the 10th century BCE and was used by the Phoenicians, the Romans, and the Merinids as a strategic port under the name Anfa.
The Portuguese destroyed them and rebuilt them under the name Casa Branca, only to abandon them after an earthquake in 1755.
The Moroccan Sultan rebuilt the city as Dar el Beida and it was named Casablanca by Spanish merchants who established trading posts there.
Casablanca is one of the least interesting places to shop in all of Morocco.

Goma is a tourist town in the Democratic Republic of the Congo in the extreme east near Rwanda.
In 2002, Goma was destroyed by the lava of the Nyiragongo volcano, which buried most of the city's streets, including the city centre.
While Goma is relatively safe, every stay outside Goma should be carefully planned to learn about the ongoing fighting in the province of North Kivu.
The city is also the starting point for climbing the volcano Nyiragongo as well as for some of the cheapest gorilla tracking tours in Africa.
You can use bodabodas (motorcycle taxis) to get around Goma. The usual (local) price is about 500 Congolese francs for the short ride.

The Kruger National Park (KNP) is in the northeast of South Africa. It borders Mozambique in the east, Zimbabwe in the north and the Crocodile River in the south.
The park has an area of 19,500 km2 and is divided into 14 different ecosystems, each of which supports a different animal population.
It is one of South Africa's main attractions and is regarded as the flagship of the South African National Parks (SANParks).
Like all South African national parks, the park charges daily conservation and entrance fees.
It may also be worth buying a Wild Card that gives access either to selected parks in South Africa or to all South African national parks.
Hong Kong Island is the namesake of the territory of Hong Kong, and it is the focus of many tourists.
The buildings that make up Hong Kong's skyline have been compared to a glittering chandelier that is visible because of the presence of the waters of Victoria Harbour.
For the best views of Hong Kong, you should leave the island and take a ferry to the opposite shore of Kowloon.
Most of the urbanization of Hong Kong Island is densely packed along the northern coast, which was reclaimed from the sea.
This is the place where the British colonists made themselves at home. If you are looking for traces of the colonial past of the area, this is a good starting point.
The Sundarbans are the largest mangrove forest in the world and stretch 80 km from the Bangladeshi and Indian hinterland to the coast.
The Sundarbans were designated as a UNESCO World Heritage Site. The part of the forest within the Indian state is called Sundarbans National Park.
The forests are not only mangrove swamps – they also include some of the last remaining stands of the mighty jungle that once covered the Ganges plain.
The Sundarbans cover an area of 3,850 km2, of which a third is covered by water and marshes.
The Sundarbans are a nature reserve since 1966, and according to estimates, there are now about 400 Bengal tigers and 30,000 spotted deer living there.

The Oyapock River Bridge is a cable-stayed bridge. It spans the Oyapock River and connects the cities of Oiapoque in Brazil and Saint-Georges de l'Oyapock in French Guiana.
Their two towers are 83 m high, their length is 378 m and they have two lanes with a width of 3.50 m.
The clearance under the bridge is 15 meters. The construction was completed in August 2011, but the opening for traffic was not until March 2017.
The bridge is expected to be fully operational in September 2017. It is hoped that the Brazilian customs posts will be completed by then.
The Guaraní were the most important indigenous group inhabiting the eastern part of Paraguay. They were semi-nomadic hunter-gatherers who also practiced subsistence agriculture.
The Chaco region was also home to other indigenous groups, such as the Guaycurú and the Payaguá, who survived by hunting, gathering, and fishing.
Paraguay, formerly known as the Great Province of the West Indies, was created in the 16th century as a result of the meeting of the Spanish conquerors with the indigenous groups.
The Spaniards began the colonization period that lasted three centuries.
Since the founding of Asuncion in 1537, Paraguay has managed to preserve much of its indigenous character and identity.
Argentina is famous for its polo team and players, who are among the best in the world.
The biggest tournament of the year takes place in December on Las Cañitas polo fields.
Smaller tournaments and competitions can be viewed at other times of the year.
Information on tournaments and ticket sales for polo matches can be found at the Argentine Polo Association.
The official currency of the Falkland Islands is the Falkland Pound (FKP), which is pegged to the value of the British Pound (GBP).
Money can be exchanged in the only bank on the island, which is opposite the FIC West Store in Stanley.
The British pound is generally accepted everywhere on the islands and at Stanley credit cards. US dollars are often accepted.
Credit cards are unlikely to be accepted on the more remote islands, although British and US currency may be accepted; find out in advance from the owners what payment methods are accepted.
It is almost impossible to exchange the currency of the Falkland Islands outside the islands themselves, so you should exchange the money before you leave the islands.
Because Montevideo is south of the equator, it is summer there when it is winter in the northern hemisphere and vice versa.
Montevideo is in the subtropics. In the summer months, temperatures over 30 °C are common.
Winter can be deceptively cool: The temperatures rarely go below freezing, but wind and humidity make it feel colder than the thermometer indicates.
There are no pronounced rainy or dry seasons: the amount of rainfall remains more or less constant throughout the year.
Although many of the animals in the park are used to seeing people, the wild animals are still wild and should not be fed or disturbed.

The section between Point Marion and Fairmount on the Highway Buffalo-Pittsburgh is probably the greatest driving challenge, as it often leads through remote, uninhabited terrain.
If you're not used to driving on highways, be careful: steep grades, narrow lanes, and sharp curves prevail here.

Spurs are aids for the feet of riders, which hang down on both sides of the saddle.
They give the rider more stability, but there are safety concerns, because the rider's feet may get caught in them.
If a rider falls off their horse and gets their foot caught in the stirrup, they can be dragged along if the horse runs on. To minimize this risk, a number of safety precautions can be taken.
First of all, most riders wear riding boots with a heel and a rather narrow sole.
In addition, some saddles, especially English saddles, have safety buckles that allow a stirrup leash to fall if pulled backwards by a falling rider.
